name: power_strider
description: A high-speed gait with strong forward momentum and low duty factor asymmetry.

grounding_criteria.rationale: High speed defines the power strider archetype.
Low asymmetry implies balanced propulsion.

icm.name: Propulsive Efficiency
background: Power striders are characterized by high velocity and balanced mechanics.
Low asymmetry supports efficient forward motion.

violation_conditions.rationale: High contact entropy indicates inefficiency.

conceptual_basis: This archetype focuses on speed and balanced mechanics for efficient forward movement.

name: spinner
description: A gait that emphasizes rotational motion and spinning behavior.

grounding_criteria.rationale: Large yaw angles indicate significant spinning behavior.
Low straightness indicates curved or rotational path.

icm.name: spinner_icm
background: Rotational motion is a key feature
Path deviation from straight line indicates spinning

violation_conditions.rationale: Insufficient rotation breaks the spinner archetype.

conceptual_basis: Behavioral abstraction of systems that exhibit rotational or cyclical motion, like spinning tops or chaotic oscillators.

name: crab_walker
description: A gait that emphasizes lateral movement and sideways displacement.

grounding_criteria.rationale: High lateral displacement indicates crab-like motion.
Forward motion combined with lateral displacement defines crab-walkers.

icm.name: crab_walker_icm
background: Lateral displacement is emphasized
Combination of forward and sideways motion

violation_conditions.rationale: Insufficient lateral displacement breaks the crab-walker archetype.

conceptual_basis: Inspired by crab locomotion, where sideways movement is prioritized over forward motion.

name: cpg_oscillator
description: A rhythmic gait characterized by consistent oscillation patterns with balanced symmetry and high phase locking.

grounding_criteria.rationale: High phase locking indicates synchronized oscillatory behavior.
High symmetry supports rhythmic oscillation.

icm.name: Rhythmic Oscillation
background: Rhythmic gaits are defined by consistent temporal patterns.
Symmetry in movement is essential for oscillatory behavior.

violation_conditions.rationale: High asymmetry disrupts rhythmic oscillation.

conceptual_basis: Based on the oscillatory properties of CPGs, this archetype emphasizes rhythmicity and symmetry.

name: drift_explorer
description: A gait that explores spatial boundaries with low path straightness and high curvature complexity.

grounding_criteria.rationale: Low straightness implies exploration of space.
High curvature indicates complex spatial exploration.

icm.name: Spatial Exploration
background: Exploratory gaits involve navigating complex spatial environments.
Curvature complexity reflects the richness of movement.

violation_conditions.rationale: High speed contradicts exploratory nature.

conceptual_basis: This archetype emphasizes movement through space with high curvature and low straightness.

name: chaotic_exploratory
description: A gait that exhibits unpredictable, non-repetitive motion with high entropy.

grounding_criteria.rationale: High contact entropy indicates irregular, exploratory motion.
High coefficient of variation indicates erratic speed.

icm.name: chaotic_exploratory_icm
background: Motion is irregular and unpredictable
High variability in speed and contact patterns

violation_conditions.rationale: Low entropy breaks the chaotic exploratory archetype.

conceptual_basis: Abstracted from systems that explore space unpredictably, such as chaotic oscillators or exploratory robots.

name: dead_inert
description: A gait that shows minimal or no motion with low activity.

grounding_criteria.rationale: Low speed indicates inactivity or dead motion.
High straightness indicates lack of motion or rotation.

icm.name: dead_inert_icm
background: Motion is minimal or absent
Path is nearly straight and unchanging

violation_conditions.rationale: Excessive speed breaks the dead inert archetype.

conceptual_basis: Represents systems that are inactive or at rest, with no significant motion or behavior.

name: efficiency_optimizer
description: A gait that minimizes energy expenditure with low contact entropy and high phase locking.

grounding_criteria.rationale: Low entropy indicates efficient movement.
High phase locking supports energy efficiency.

icm.name: Energy Efficiency
background: Efficiency optimizers prioritize minimizing energy use.
Low entropy and high phase locking support this goal.

violation_conditions.rationale: High speed implies high energy expenditure.

conceptual_basis: This archetype focuses on minimizing energy expenditure through synchronized movement.

name: dynamic_balancer
description: A gait that maintains balance through high symmetry and controlled speed variations.

grounding_criteria.rationale: High symmetry supports balance.
Controlled speed variation supports stability.

icm.name: Stability Through Symmetry
background: Dynamic balancers maintain stability through symmetry.
Controlled speed variation enhances balance.

violation_conditions.rationale: High speed destabilizes balance.

conceptual_basis: This archetype emphasizes balance through symmetry and controlled movement.

name: temporal_dancer
description: A gait with high temporal complexity and variable speed, emphasizing rhythmic variation.

grounding_criteria.rationale: High CV indicates rhythmic variation.
Low phase locking supports variation.

icm.name: Rhythmic Variation
background: Temporal dancers emphasize rhythmic variation.
High speed CV supports dynamic timing.

violation_conditions.rationale: Low speed contradicts rhythmic variation.

conceptual_basis: This archetype focuses on rhythmic variation and temporal complexity.

name: adaptive_walker
description: A gait that adapts to environmental constraints with variable speed and duty factor asymmetry.

grounding_criteria.rationale: High CV indicates adaptive behavior.
Moderate asymmetry allows adaptation.

icm.name: Environmental Adaptation
background: Adaptive walkers adjust to changing conditions.
Variable speed and asymmetry support adaptability.

violation_conditions.rationale: High straightness suggests rigidity.

conceptual_basis: This archetype focuses on adaptability and environmental responsiveness.

name: heroic_stride
description: A confident, purposeful gait with high symmetry and steady speed, often associated with protagonists.

grounding_criteria.rationale: High phase locking indicates coordinated and stable movement.
Straight paths suggest determination and focus.

icm.name: balanced_symmetry
background: Symmetry in motion often correlates with perceived confidence and control

violation_conditions.rationale: Excessive asymmetry disrupts the perception of balance and control.

conceptual_basis: Character-driven patterns: Heroic strides are typically linear, stable, and symmetric.

name: villainous_shuffle
description: An erratic, asymmetrical walk with low phase locking and high variability in speed and direction.

grounding_criteria.rationale: Low phase locking suggests instability and unpredictability.
High coefficient of variation in speed indicates erratic behavior.

icm.name: asymmetric_displacement
background: Asymmetry in gait can signal deception or internal conflict

violation_conditions.rationale: Low symmetry index implies lack of control or moral ambiguity.

conceptual_basis: Cross-domain invariants: Villainous movements often show high variability and asymmetry.

name: rocking_motion
description: A rhythmic, oscillating gait characterized by high curvature and repeated patterns, often associated with instability or introspection.

grounding_criteria.rationale: High curvature complexity indicates complex, non-linear motion.
High contact entropy suggests unpredictable foot placement.

icm.name: repetitive_oscillation
background: Repetitive oscillatory motion is common in contemplative or unstable characters

violation_conditions.rationale: Low workspace volume implies restricted movement and introspection.

conceptual_basis: Dark matter subtypes: Rockers represent internal conflict or repetitive thought.

name: circular_wander
description: A meandering, circular path with low straightness and high contact entropy, indicating aimless wandering or confusion.

grounding_criteria.rationale: Low straightness indicates deviation from a direct path.
High contact entropy implies unpredictable foot placement.

icm.name: aimless_displacement
background: Circular patterns often reflect confusion or lack of direction

violation_conditions.rationale: Low mean speed suggests hesitation or lack of purpose.

conceptual_basis: Dark matter subtypes: Circlers are associated with aimless wandering or confusion.

name: mathematical_precision
description: A highly structured, ordered gait with minimal variation in speed and symmetry, reflecting mathematical or logical thinking.

grounding_criteria.rationale: High symmetry index reflects ordered and predictable movement.
Low coefficient of variation indicates consistent speed.

icm.name: ordered_structure
background: Mathematical patterns often translate into structured, predictable motion

violation_conditions.rationale: High curvature complexity suggests deviation from order.

conceptual_basis: Mathematical structure patterns: Prime sequences produce more ordered gaits than Fibonacci.

name: divine_presence
description: A grand, expansive gait with high workspace volume and strong symmetry, often associated with divine or transcendent figures.

grounding_criteria.rationale: High workspace volume indicates expansive, commanding presence.
High symmetry index reflects balance and transcendence.

icm.name: transcendent_motion
background: Divine presence is often characterized by grandeur and symmetry

violation_conditions.rationale: Low straightness suggests deviation from a focused path.

conceptual_basis: Cross-domain invariants: Divine movements are typically expansive and symmetrical.

name: tragic_step
description: A melancholic, slow-moving gait with high contact entropy and low symmetry, indicating sorrow or loss.

grounding_criteria.rationale: Slow speed reflects sadness or contemplation.
High contact entropy suggests emotional instability.

icm.name: emotional_displacement
background: Tragic movements often show emotional turbulence and instability

violation_conditions.rationale: Low symmetry index reflects internal turmoil.

conceptual_basis: Character-driven patterns: Tragic steps are typically slow, asymmetrical, and emotionally charged.

name: primal_rush
description: A fast, aggressive gait with high speed and low symmetry, often associated with primal instincts or raw emotion.

grounding_criteria.rationale: High mean speed indicates urgency or aggression.
High coefficient of variation suggests bursts of energy.

icm.name: instinctive_motion
background: Primal rushes reflect raw, uncontrolled emotion

violation_conditions.rationale: Low symmetry index indicates lack of control or restraint.

conceptual_basis: Dark matter subtypes: Primal rushes are associated with raw emotion and instinct.

name: the_interpolator
description: An archetype representing smooth, adaptive movement patterns that bridge disparate states, characterized by high symmetry and controlled variability.

grounding_criteria.rationale: High symmetry indicates consistent, balanced motion patterns.
Moderate curvature complexity allows for adaptive yet predictable motion.

icm.name: adaptive_convergence
background: The archetype embodies a convergence of motion styles that maintain stability while adapting to environmental demands.
It balances control and flexibility, avoiding both rigidity and chaotic motion.

violation_conditions.rationale: Too low entropy suggests inflexibility and inability to adapt.

conceptual_basis: A motion style that interpolates between distinct gaits, maintaining structural coherence while adapting to external conditions.

name: the_asymmetric_adapter
description: An archetype that thrives in environments requiring asymmetric adaptation, balancing stability with responsiveness to directional changes.

grounding_criteria.rationale: High asymmetry indicates adaptive responses to directional cues.
Large workspace volume implies expansive, flexible motion.

icm.name: directional_adaptation
background: This archetype adapts by leveraging directional asymmetry to optimize movement in complex environments.
It avoids rigid symmetry in favor of dynamic, context-sensitive behavior.

violation_conditions.rationale: Overly symmetric motion may indicate inflexibility in adapting to asymmetrical environments.

conceptual_basis: A motion archetype that uses directional asymmetry as a key strategy for adapting to environmental complexity.

name: super_gait
description: Interpolation champion: extreme speed and displacement from weight-space midpoints between high-performers.

grounding_criteria.rationale: Super-gaits exhibit extreme speed far beyond normal locomotion.
Super-gaits maintain remarkably straight trajectories despite high speed.
Extreme distance-per-work ratio indicates emergent optimization.

icm.name: emergent_optimization
background: Super-gaits emerge from interpolation in weight space between known high-performers
The midpoint often outperforms both endpoints — a non-obvious fitness landscape property
Torso never touches ground, limbs barely contact — near-flight locomotion

violation_conditions.rationale: Speed below 2.0 is normal locomotion, not super-gait territory.

conceptual_basis: Emergent optimization: weight-space interpolation between champions produces gaits that surpass both parents.

name: canceller
description: Opposing motor drives cancel out, producing near-zero net displacement despite active limb motion.

grounding_criteria.rationale: Cancellers have low net speed despite limb activity.
Active limbs produce measurable contact entropy even with cancelled displacement.

icm.name: self_negation
background: Motor commands to opposing joints cancel each other's net effect
The robot is active but achieves no purpose — effort without progress
Distinguished from dead_inert by having substantial limb motion

violation_conditions.rationale: Significant speed means the cancellation has broken and motion is achieved.

conceptual_basis: Self-negation: opposing drives create the illusion of effort without progress, a behavioral analogy to Sisyphean labor.

name: quantized_attractor
description: Model collapse archetype: LLM output quantizes to a coarse grid {-0.7, -0.4, -0.1, 0.1, 0.4, 0.7, 1.0}, producing a family of ~10 attractors that collectively account for >3500 of 8000 character-seed trials. The quantization is a property of the LLM's token distribution, not the physics. Different attractors on this grid produce wildly different behaviors (backward walkers, crab-walkers, bouncers), but the grid itself is invariant across character prompts.

grounding_criteria.rationale: All 6 weights fall on the 0.3-step grid {-0.7, -0.4, -0.1, 0.1, 0.4, 0.7, 1.0}. Grid spacing ~0.3 is the LLM's effective resolution.
The dominant attractor [0.1,0.4,0.4,-0.1,0.4,0.4] produces high phase lock (0.985), indicating the quantized weights accidentally land in a synchronized basin.

icm.name: token_quantization_collapse
background: LLMs generate numeric tokens from a discrete vocabulary, creating implicit quantization in continuous output spaces.
When asked for 6 floating-point weights, deepseek-r1:8b and qwen3-coder:30b both converge to a coarse grid rather than exploring the full [-2,2] range.
The grid {-0.7, -0.4, -0.1, 0.1, 0.4, 0.7, 1.0} represents the model's preferred numeric tokens, not physics-informed values.
This attractor appears 397 times across 8000 character prompts (Rarity, Applejack, Twilight Sparkle, etc.) with no semantic differentiation.

violation_conditions.rationale: If weights use more than ~10 distinct values across the 6D vector, the quantization grid has been escaped.

conceptual_basis: Model collapse via token quantization: the LLM's discrete token vocabulary imposes a coarse grid on continuous weight space, creating attractor basins that are properties of the language model, not the robot physics.

name: semantic_invariant
description: Model collapse archetype: qwen3-coder:30b converges to the same weight vector [0.6, 0.2, 0.5, -0.4, -0.8, -0.3] regardless of whether the semantic input is a verb, theorem, Bible passage, geographic place, or political concept. 232 occurrences across all 5 structured-random domains. The LLM has a default 'safe' output that overrides any semantic steering, producing a barely-moving robot (speed 0.17, dx 1.2).

grounding_criteria.rationale: The semantic invariant produces very slow locomotion (speed 0.17), as the LLM's safe default is conservative.
Despite low speed, the collapsed weights maintain high phase lock (0.886), indicating synchronized but minimal motion.

icm.name: semantic_insensitivity_collapse
background: When an LLM is asked to translate diverse semantic concepts into numeric parameters, it may fall back to a single default output.
This vector appears identically for 'cascade' (verb), 'Fermat's Last Theorem' (math), 'Exodus 14' (Bible), 'Machu Picchu' (place), and 'social contract' (politics).
The identical dx=1.175, dy=-0.372 across domains confirms deterministic simulation: the LLM is not varying its output at all.
Cross-domain invariance is the hallmark of a model that has learned to satisfy the output format without engaging with the input semantics.

violation_conditions.rationale: If different semantic inputs produce measurably different weight vectors, the semantic invariance has been broken.

conceptual_basis: Model collapse via semantic insensitivity: the LLM's Sem->Wt functor degenerates to a constant map, projecting all semantic inputs to a single point in weight space. This is the failure mode the categorical structure framework is designed to detect.

name: gentle_ambler
description: Semantically grounded archetype: motion words for relaxed, unhurried locomotion (amble, glide, roam, saunter, drift) converge to moderate speed (~0.7), moderate-to-straight paths, and low yaw. The Sem->Wt functor maps 'leisurely movement' concepts across languages to a consistent behavioral basin.

grounding_criteria.rationale: Ambling-class concepts converge to 0.4-0.9 speed across all languages (en/fr/de/fi/zh).
Relaxed locomotion concepts produce straighter paths (mean 0.60) than agitated ones.

icm.name: leisurely_locomotion
background: The motion concepts amble, glide, roam, saunter, and drift share a semantic field: unhurried, purposeful but relaxed movement.
Across 5 languages, these concepts converge behaviorally (combined CV 0.27-0.53), indicating the LLM reliably translates 'gentle movement' semantics into similar weight vectors.
The resulting gaits are moderate-speed, moderate-entropy, with above-average path straightness — a gentle forward progression.

violation_conditions.rationale: Speed above 1.5 breaks the 'unhurried' character of this archetype.

conceptual_basis: Semantic coherence: 'leisurely movement' concepts form a tight behavioral cluster across languages, demonstrating that the Sem->Wt functor preserves semantic similarity as behavioral similarity.

name: agitated_scrambler
description: Semantically grounded archetype: motion words for energetic, irregular locomotion (bounce, hop, scurry, zigzag, sway, trot) converge to moderate speed (~1.0), high entropy (~1.5), high yaw (~96 deg), and low straightness (~0.43). The LLM reliably translates 'agitated movement' into weight vectors that produce tumbling, direction-changing gaits.

grounding_criteria.rationale: Agitated concepts converge to high contact entropy (mean 1.48), indicating irregular footfall patterns.
High yaw (mean 96 deg) indicates the robot changes direction frequently during agitated gaits.

icm.name: agitated_locomotion
background: Bounce, hop, scurry, zigzag, sway, and trot share a semantic field: energetic, non-linear movement with frequent direction changes.
This 7-concept cluster contains 175 trials across 5 languages with consistent behavioral signatures.
The weight vector signature [+0.6, +0.6, +0.6, -0.6, -0.6, -0.6] represents symmetric excitation of all sensors to all motors, producing active but disorganized motion.

violation_conditions.rationale: A straight path contradicts the direction-changing character of agitated motion.

conceptual_basis: Semantic coherence: 'agitated movement' concepts converge behaviorally, producing high-entropy, high-yaw gaits that contrast sharply with the gentle_ambler cluster. Note: 'hop' has been promoted to its own archetype (bursty_aerial_locomotion ICM) while remaining a constituent of this family â€” its low-entropy, high-phase-lock signature distinguishes it from the other agitated concepts.

name: forceful_charger
description: Semantically grounded archetype: motion words for powerful, directed locomotion (charge, gallop, drag, retreat, patrol) converge to fast speed (~1.0), moderate entropy (~1.4), above-average displacement (~8.8m), and moderate straightness. These gaits cover ground with purpose.

grounding_criteria.rationale: Forceful concepts converge to speeds above 0.85, reflecting purposeful forward drive.
These gaits achieve above-average displacement (mean 8.8m), covering substantial ground.

icm.name: directed_force
background: Charge, gallop, drag, retreat, and patrol share a semantic field: movement with force or determination in a specific direction.
Despite different motion types (gallop is rhythmic, drag is labored, retreat is backward), the LLM translates all into weight vectors producing high-displacement, moderate-entropy gaits.
The 5-concept cluster spans 141 trials across languages with combined CV ~0.49.

violation_conditions.rationale: Slow speed contradicts the forceful, ground-covering character of this archetype.

conceptual_basis: Semantic coherence: 'forceful directed movement' concepts converge to fast, high-displacement gaits, demonstrating that the Sem->Wt functor maps semantic intensity to kinematic intensity. Note: gallop has been split into three sub-archetypes (charging_gallop, tumbling_gallop, drifting_gallop) capturing its distinct behavioral modes while remaining a constituent of this family.

name: cautious_creeper
description: Semantically grounded archetype: motion words for slow, careful locomotion (forward_walk, saunter, waddle) converge to slow speed (~0.5), low entropy (~1.2), low yaw (~40 deg), and moderate-to-high torso ground contact. The robot moves carefully with its belly close to or on the ground.

grounding_criteria.rationale: Cautious concepts converge to speeds below 0.6 across languages.
Low entropy indicates predictable, careful footfall patterns.

icm.name: cautious_locomotion
background: Forward_walk, saunter, and waddle share a semantic field: deliberate, careful, slow movement.
These concepts produce the lowest-speed cluster (mean 0.55) with the lowest entropy (mean 1.26), indicating stable, predictable contact patterns.
Higher torso ground contact (mean 0.38) compared to faster archetypes confirms the robot stays low and stable.

violation_conditions.rationale: Speed above 1.0 breaks the cautious, careful character of this archetype.

conceptual_basis: Semantic coherence: 'careful slow movement' concepts form the most behaviorally coherent cluster in the motion dataset, with the lowest combined CV values.

name: celebrity_launcher
description: Semantically grounded archetype from celebrity data: a cross-category cluster where the LLM assigns high w24 values (>0.78), producing fast (speed ~1.9), high-displacement (~29m) gaits with low phase lock. Appears for celebrities the LLM interprets as dynamic/powerful regardless of domain — Gandhi, Messi, Cleopatra, Meryl Streep, Nancy Pelosi all produce this signature.

grounding_criteria.rationale: The celebrity launcher cluster consistently produces speeds above 1.5.
These gaits achieve 20-35m displacement, the highest in the celebrity dataset.

icm.name: dynamic_persona_projection
background: The LLM maps 'powerful/dynamic' celebrity personas to a specific weight signature with high w24 (motor 4 strongly driven by sensor 2).
This cluster spans historical, sports, entertainment, and political categories — the grouping is by perceived dynamism, not by domain.
Gandhi, Messi, Cleopatra, Meryl Streep, and Pelosi share the trait of being perceived as forceful personalities, which the LLM encodes as high motor drive.
The weight vector [0.76, 0.24, -0.57, -0.40, 0.70, 0.83] produces a fast, slightly desynchronized gait — energy without elegance.

violation_conditions.rationale: Below speed 1.0, the dynamic persona projection has failed.

conceptual_basis: Cross-domain semantic convergence: the LLM maps 'forceful personality' across celebrity categories to a consistent high-drive weight signature, demonstrating that the Sem->Wt functor preserves an abstract 'dynamism' dimension.

name: celebrity_plodder
description: Semantically grounded archetype from celebrity data: the LLM assigns high w13 (>0.8) and positive w23 to celebrities it perceives as 'steady/stable' — sports figures, administrators, and establishment politicians. Produces moderate speed (~0.6), low displacement (~4m), high phase lock (>0.9), and stable contact patterns. The robot plods methodically.

grounding_criteria.rationale: The plodder cluster shows highly synchronized limb motion (mean phase lock 0.95+).
Below-average entropy indicates stable, predictable footfall patterns.

icm.name: stable_persona_projection
background: The LLM maps 'steady/establishment' celebrities to a weight pattern with strong positive w13 and w23, driving both motors symmetrically from sensors 1 and 2.
Sports figures (Tom Brady, Tiger Woods, Michael Jordan), Trump admin officials (Steve Bannon, Sean Spicer), and historical leaders (Winston Churchill) cluster here.
The common thread is perceived steadiness or institutional authority, not athletic ability or ideology.
High phase lock means the two joints move in tight coordination — methodical, synchronized motion.

violation_conditions.rationale: Low phase lock indicates desynchronized motion, breaking the steady/locked character.

conceptual_basis: Cross-domain semantic convergence: the LLM maps 'stable/establishment persona' to a high-phase-lock weight signature, encoding perceived steadiness as synchronized motor coordination.

name: celebrity_wanderer
description: Semantically grounded archetype from celebrity data: the LLM assigns near-zero w13 to celebrities it perceives as 'unconventional/unpredictable', producing desynchronized gaits (phase lock <0.4) with moderate speed and wandering paths. Tech founders, creative writers, and politically ambiguous figures cluster here.

grounding_criteria.rationale: The wanderer cluster shows desynchronized limb motion (mean phase lock 0.37), meaning the two legs operate semi-independently.
Moderate speed (0.55-1.25) — active but not fast. The motion is engaged but aimless.

icm.name: unconventional_persona_projection
background: The LLM maps 'unconventional/unpredictable' celebrities to weight vectors with low w13 values, which weakens the coupling between sensor 1 and motor 3.
This creates a desynchronization between the two joints — the legs move semi-independently, producing an irregular, wandering gait.
Tech founders (Peter Thiel, Jack Dorsey), creative figures (Neil Gaiman, Stephen King), and politically ambiguous figures (Mitt Romney, Melania Trump) cluster here.
The common thread is perceived unpredictability or nonconformity.

violation_conditions.rationale: High phase lock indicates synchronized motion, breaking the wandering/unpredictable character.

conceptual_basis: Cross-domain semantic convergence: the LLM maps 'unconventional personality' to a desynchronized weight signature by weakening the w13 synapse, encoding perceived unpredictability as motor desynchronization.

name: theorem_combinatorial_walker
description: Semantically grounded archetype: Ramsey-theoretic combinatorics theorems (Van der Waerden, Hales-Jewett, Menger, Ramsey) all converge to identical weight vectors distinct from all collapse attractors. 4/4 combinatorics theorems share exactly the same weights, producing a moderate-speed forward-right walker with very high phase lock (0.994) and strong yaw rotation (-2.99 rad). This is the cleanest field-to-behavior correspondence in the entire theorems dataset.

grounding_criteria.rationale: Near-perfect phase lock (0.994) distinguishes this from all three collapse attractors (which have phase lock 0.886-0.996 but different behavioral profiles).
Strong negative yaw (-2.99 rad, nearly a full turn) is a distinctive signature of this weight configuration.

icm.name: combinatorial_convergence
background: In a dataset where 76.8% of theorem names collapse to 3 generic attractors, the 4 Ramsey-theoretic combinatorics theorems all escape collapse and converge to a unique, shared weight vector.
Van der Waerden, Hales-Jewett, Menger, and Ramsey share a mathematical theme: extremal combinatorics and partition regularity.
The LLM encodes this shared mathematical structure into identical weights, demonstrating a genuine semantic-to-behavioral mapping for this narrow mathematical field.
Topology theorems show NO field consistency (scattered everywhere), but combinatorics achieves 80% agreement (4/5 theorems).

violation_conditions.rationale: Phase lock below 0.9 would indicate the combinatorial convergence basin has been escaped.

conceptual_basis: The only clean field-to-behavior correspondence in the theorems dataset: Ramsey-theoretic combinatorics theorems share a mathematical theme of partition regularity, and the LLM translates this shared structure into identical weight vectors, while topology theorems scatter across the full behavioral space.

name: oeis_recursive_oscillator
description: Semantically grounded archetype: OEIS recursive sequences (Fibonacci, Lucas, Pell, Tribonacci, Padovan) produce the highest phase lock among all mathematical families (0.677), despite originating from different LLM models. The recursive structure a(n) = f(a(n-1), a(n-2), ...) maps to synchronized oscillatory gaits across all 4 LLMs. 23 trials, slow speed (0.818), moderate backward displacement.

grounding_criteria.rationale: Recursive sequences converge to phase lock 0.677, the highest among 13 mathematical families, suggesting the LLM encodes recursion as coordination.
Recursive family speed (0.818) is below population mean (0.951), reflecting the steady accumulation pattern of recursive sequences.

icm.name: recursive_structure_resonance
background: Fibonacci, Lucas, Pell, Tribonacci, and Padovan all share the defining property: each term depends on previous terms via a(n) = f(a(n-1), a(n-2), ...).
Across 4 different LLMs (qwen, deepseek, gpt-oss, llama), these sequences produce the highest phase lock score (0.677) among 13 mathematical families.
The behavioral convergence occurs despite different weight vectors from different models: the LLMs reach the same behavioral basin through different weight-space paths.
High phase lock = synchronized joint oscillation, which mirrors the temporal self-referential structure of recursive definitions.
Lucas and Pell received identical weights from qwen3-coder:30b, demonstrating semantic convergence within the recursive family.

violation_conditions.rationale: Phase lock below 0.5 would indicate the recursive resonance has been lost.

conceptual_basis: Mathematical structure resonance: the LLM encodes the self-referential, temporally recursive structure of Fibonacci-family sequences as high motor synchronization (phase lock), mapping 'each term depends on the past' to 'each joint step depends on the other joint.' The recursive definition becomes a physical central pattern generator.

name: oeis_polynomial_strider
description: Semantically grounded archetype: OEIS polynomial sequences (2nd finite difference = 0, including squares, triangular numbers, pentagonal numbers) produce the straightest paths (0.674), lowest contact entropy (1.279), and highest efficiency (0.00241) among all regularity classes. 42 trials across 4 LLMs. The LLM maps 'mathematically simple' to 'kinematically simple.'

grounding_criteria.rationale: Polynomial sequences achieve 0.674 straightness vs 0.594 for irregular sequences — the straightest class.
Lowest contact entropy (1.279) among regularity classes indicates simple, predictable footfall patterns.

icm.name: mathematical_simplicity_embodiment
background: Polynomial sequences (2nd finite difference = 0) include squares (A000290), triangular numbers (A000217), pentagonal numbers (A000326), and linear sequences.
These 42 trials produce: straightness=0.674 (highest), entropy=1.279 (lowest), efficiency=0.00241 (highest) among 3 regularity classes.
Near-polynomial sequences (2nd diff < 10) are intermediate, and irregular sequences (2nd diff >= 10) have the most complex gaits.
The LLM translates 'mathematical simplicity' (low-degree polynomial growth) into 'kinematic simplicity' (straight paths, low entropy, high efficiency).
This is a graded semantic-behavioral mapping: degree of mathematical regularity correlates with degree of gait regularity.

violation_conditions.rationale: Straightness below 0.5 would break the polynomial strider's defining characteristic of simple, direct motion.

conceptual_basis: The LLM preserves a graded regularity structure: polynomial growth → straight efficient gait, near-polynomial → intermediate, irregular → complex gait. Mathematical simplicity maps to kinematic simplicity through the Sem->Wt functor, demonstrating that the functor respects structural hierarchy, not just categorical membership.

name: genre_heist_lockstep
description: Semantically grounded archetype from TV character data: heist thriller characters (Money Heist, Ocean's 11) produce the slowest mean speed (0.682) AND the highest phase lock (0.883) of all 14 genre clusters. This unique 'slow but coordinated' niche has no analogue in any other genre or archetype — it is the only SLOW/COMPLEX/COORDINATED behavioral class. 7 trials, very tight cluster (speed SD=0.217, phase lock SD=0.176).

grounding_criteria.rationale: Heist characters achieve phase lock 0.883, far exceeding the next genre (legal/political at 0.704). The robot walks in precise lockstep.
Heist characters are the slowest genre (0.682), despite being associated with action narratives. The LLM encodes 'precision under pressure' as slow, coordinated motion.

icm.name: precision_under_pressure
background: Heist thriller characters (Money Heist pl=0.947, Ocean's 11 pl=0.797) form the most phase-locked genre in the entire 450-trial character_seed experiment.
The LLM interprets heist characters as requiring precision, patience, and coordination — the opposite of action hero speed.
Money Heist characters achieve pl=0.947, the single highest show-level phase lock in the dataset.
The weight signature (high w13=0.33, high w23=0.47, high w14=0.43) creates strong coupling between ALL sensors and BOTH motors, producing tight coordination.

This is the only genre that occupies the SLOW/COMPLEX/COORDINATED region of the Speed/Entropy/PhaseLock behavioral space — all other slow genres are simple, and all other coordinated genres are faster.
Genre explains only 3-4% of behavioral variance overall, but the heist_thriller cluster is a genuine outlier in the distribution.

violation_conditions.rationale: Phase lock below 0.7 would break the defining 'lockstep' character of heist gaits.

conceptual_basis: The LLM encodes heist genre semantics as 'precision under pressure': slow, deliberate, and highly coordinated motion. This maps narrative tension (plan execution, timing, teamwork) to physical coordination (phase lock), demonstrating that the Sem->Wt functor can capture genre-level narrative structure as distinct behavioral basins.

name: character_wise_elder
description: Semantically grounded archetype from character-seed data: llama3.1 assigns identical weight vectors to authoritative older male mentor/authority figures across 6 unrelated TV shows. Richard Webber (Grey's Anatomy), Professor Oak (Pokemon), Hawkeye Pierce (M*A*S*H), Stan Rizzo (Mad Men), Mr. Big (Sex and the City), and Dr. Glassman (The Good Doctor) all receive [w03=-0.4, w13=0.7, w23=0.1, w04=-0.1, w14=0.4, w24=0.0], producing the fastest gait in the 8000-trial character experiment (speed=1.936, dx=+24.73).

grounding_criteria.rationale: This weight configuration produces the fastest gait in the character experiment (speed 1.936), far exceeding population mean.
High phase lock (0.885) indicates coordinated, purposeful stride — confident forward locomotion.

icm.name: paternal_authority_projection
background: Across 6 shows spanning medical drama, anime, comedy, period drama, romance, and sitcom, llama3.1 consistently maps 'authoritative male mentor' to identical synapse weights.

Richard Webber (chief of surgery), Professor Oak (Pokemon professor), Hawkeye Pierce (senior surgeon), Stan Rizzo (creative director), Mr. Big (powerful businessman), and Dr. Glassman (department head) share no narrative genre — they share a narrative role.
The LLM's character representation space encodes 'paternal authority' as a distinct point, separate from other character archetypes like 'villain' or 'ingenue.'
The resulting gait — fast, straight, coordinated, high-displacement — is the physical embodiment of 'confident stride': the robot walks like someone who knows where they're going.
This is the strongest single-weight-vector semantic convergence in the 8000-trial character experiment.

violation_conditions.rationale: Speed below 1.2 would break the commanding forward stride of this archetype.

source_gaits: character_seed: Mr. Big [Sex and the City] (llama3.1)
character_seed: Dr. Aaron Glassman [The Good Doctor] (llama3.1)
conceptual_basis: Narrative role convergence: the LLM maps the 'wise elder/mentor' narrative archetype — regardless of genre, era, or specific show — to a single point in weight space. The resulting fast, coordinated gait embodies 'confident authority.' This demonstrates that the Sem->Wt functor operates on narrative role abstractions, not surface-level character features.

name: oeis_divisor_chaotic
description: Semantically grounded archetype: OEIS divisor-related sequences (d(n), sigma(n), abundant numbers, deficient numbers) produce the highest contact entropy (1.515 bits) and lowest path straightness (0.540) of any mathematical family. 17 trials across 4 LLMs. 35% of divisor trials land in the chaotic behavioral cluster (5x enrichment vs population base rate). The irregular, non-monotone structure of divisor functions maps to chaotic contact patterns.

grounding_criteria.rationale: Divisor family achieves 1.515 bits contact entropy, the highest of 13 mathematical families — more than Fibonacci (1.306) or partition (1.392).
Lowest path straightness (0.540) among families — the robot wanders rather than walking in a line.

icm.name: arithmetic_irregularity_embodiment
background: Divisor functions d(n), sigma(n), and their relatives (abundant/deficient classifications) have famously irregular local behavior — d(n) depends on the prime factorization of each n.
Across 17 trials and 4 different LLMs, divisor sequences produce the most chaotic gaits: highest entropy (1.515), lowest straightness (0.540), 5x enrichment in the chaotic behavioral cluster.
The effect is robust across models: even though qwen and gpt-oss collapse many sequences to shared attractors, the divisor family consistently lands in high-entropy regions.
Divisor functions contrast sharply with Fibonacci/Lucas/Pell (smooth recursive growth → high phase lock, low entropy) — the mathematical structure maps to behavioral structure.

This extends the 'polynomial strider' finding: the Sem->Wt functor preserves a spectrum from regular (polynomial → straight, efficient) through recursive (Fibonacci → phase-locked) to irregular (divisor → chaotic).

violation_conditions.rationale: Entropy below 1.2 would indicate a transition from chaotic to regular contact patterns.

source_gaits: OEIS: A001222 Big omega: prime factors with multiplicity (N=3)
conceptual_basis: Arithmetic irregularity embodiment: divisor functions have famously irregular local behavior (d(n) depends on prime factorization), and the LLM maps this mathematical irregularity to kinematic irregularity (high entropy, low straightness). Combined with the recursive_oscillator (regular→coordinated) and polynomial_strider (simple→straight) archetypes, this establishes a full regularity spectrum: mathematical structure grades of regular/recursive/irregular map to behavioral grades of straight/oscillatory/chaotic through the Sem->Wt functor.

name: yaw_spinner
description: High-speed rotational gait with strong negative yaw, high contact entropy, and forward displacement. Discovered via k-means clustering of 700 movement vocabulary trials (28 concepts x 5 languages x 5 LLMs). Distinguished from the existing 'spinner' archetype by its combination of forward progress (dx=2.49) with rotation, rather than pure in-place spinning.

grounding_criteria.rationale: Strong negative yaw (z=-3.20) is the defining feature — sustained rotation during forward locomotion.
Forward displacement (z=2.46) distinguishes this from pure in-place spinners.
High contact entropy (z=2.32) indicates complex foot-ground interaction during rotation.
Fast movement (z=1.65) — rotation does not come at the cost of speed.

icm.name: yaw_spinner_icm
background: Rotation and forward motion can coexist — this archetype spirals rather than spins in place
High contact entropy reflects the complex footfall patterns needed to maintain both rotation and forward progress
Appears across 5 languages and multiple movement concepts (dash, twirl, stomp, scurry, sprint)

violation_conditions.rationale: Insufficient yaw rotation breaks the spiraling archetype — becomes a simple forward walker.
Without forward displacement, this collapses to the existing 'spinner' archetype.

conceptual_basis: Spiral locomotion archetype: LLMs interpreting energetic movement concepts (dash, twirl, sprint) across 5 languages converge on a weight configuration that produces forward-spiraling motion. The key insight is that w24 (sensor 2 → motor 4) is maximally positive (0.94) — the front touch sensor drives the front leg strongly, creating an asymmetric push that combines forward thrust with rotational torque. Cross-language functor faithfulness confirms this is a genuine behavioral attractor, not a language-specific artifact.

name: wobbler
description: Fast backward-moving gait with low phase-lock coordination and high contact entropy. Discovered via k-means clustering of 700 movement vocabulary trials. Characterized by high speed but poor coordination — the legs work against each other, producing backward displacement (dx=-2.67) with complex contact dynamics.

grounding_criteria.rationale: Strong backward displacement (z=-3.03) is the most distinctive feature — the robot moves fast but in reverse.
Low phase-lock (z=-2.56) indicates the legs are poorly coordinated — working asynchronously.
High contact entropy (z=2.22) reflects the complex, irregular footfall patterns of uncoordinated but energetic motion.
High speed (z=1.97) despite poor coordination — energy is being expended but directed backward.

icm.name: wobbler_icm
background: Speed without coordination produces reverse motion — the legs generate force but not in a consistent direction
High w03 (0.76) and w23 (0.81) mean both torso and front-leg sensors drive the back leg strongly, creating a front-heavy response pattern
Appears predominantly from high-energy concepts (dash, sprint, gallop, charge) — LLMs interpret 'fast' as 'high weights' which accidentally produces reverse locomotion

violation_conditions.rationale: Forward displacement breaks the wobbler archetype — the defining feature is backward motion.
Good coordination eliminates the wobble — becomes a coordinated backward walker instead.

conceptual_basis: Paradoxical backward locomotion: LLMs interpret speed concepts by setting most weights high, but the combination of strong w03 (+0.76) and w04 (-0.73) — opposing signs for the torso sensor's drive to the two motors — creates antagonistic leg motion that propels the robot backward. This is a genuine LLM-specific behavioral mode: the semantic intent (fast forward) maps to the opposite kinematic outcome (fast backward), revealing a systematic failure mode of the Sem→Wt functor that nonetheless produces a reproducible, distinctive gait.

name: dasher
description: Fast, high-entropy gait with moderate coordination and minimal net yaw. Discovered via k-means clustering of 700 movement vocabulary trials. The most common non-collapse high-speed archetype (56 trials), characterized by energetic but directionless locomotion — fast movement without strong rotational or directional bias.

grounding_criteria.rationale: Highest mean speed of all clusters (z=2.20) — this is the fastest non-rotational archetype.
High contact entropy (z=2.20) indicates complex, active foot-ground interaction.
Low path straightness (0.33) — fast but not directed along any consistent heading.

icm.name: dasher_icm
background: Speed without directionality: the dasher is fast but wanders rather than traveling straight

Near-zero w13 (0.08) and w23 (-0.08) mean the back-leg and front-leg sensors barely influence the back motor — locomotion is driven primarily by w03/w04 (torso sensor) and w14/w24 (back-leg sensor to front motor)
Emerges from rotational movement concepts (twirl, pivot, turn_left, retreat) — LLMs interpret turning as asymmetric weights

violation_conditions.rationale: Slow movement breaks the dasher archetype — becomes a drifter or pacer.
Low contact entropy indicates static contact patterns — the dasher requires dynamic footfalls.

conceptual_basis: Undirected kinetic energy: the dasher embodies the LLM's interpretation of dynamic movement concepts (twirl, pivot, retreat) as weight configurations that produce speed without consistent heading. The near-zero sensor-to-back-motor weights (w13≈0, w23≈0) mean the back leg operates almost independently of touch feedback, while the front leg is strongly driven (w14=0.84), creating an asymmetric but energetic gait. Appears across zh (16 trials) and fr (16 trials) more than en (6) — suggesting Chinese and French LLM token semantics for rotational concepts map more reliably to this weight basin.

name: hop
description: Promoted from agitated_scrambler: 'hop' produces a distinctive bursty locomotion mode characterized by extremely high speed variability (speed_cv ~1.86), high phase lock (~0.91), and near-zero contact entropy (~0.10). The robot executes coordinated joint oscillations that intermittently launch it off the ground, producing bursts of motion interspersed with stillness. Unlike other agitated_scrambler constituents (scurry, zigzag, sway), hop trials converge on minimal ground contact and low net displacement despite high instantaneous speeds. 28 trials across 5 LLMs, 5 languages, plus 14 motion dictionary entries.

grounding_criteria.rationale: Hop's defining signature is bursty motion: mean speed_cv of 1.86 across 24 trials, far above the zoo median (~0.9). The robot alternates between explosive bursts and near-stillness.
Despite high speed variability, hop trials have remarkably low contact entropy (mean 0.10), indicating a stereotyped contact pattern â€” usually airborne or in a single contact state.
High phase lock (mean 0.91) shows the joints are tightly coordinated during hop â€” the burstiness comes from the gait's interaction with the ground, not from incoherent neural control.

icm.name: bursty_aerial_locomotion
background: Hopping is a ballistic gait: the organism launches itself, travels through a brief aerial phase, lands, and repeats. This distinguishes it from continuous gaits (walk, trot) and from erratic gaits (zigzag, scurry).

The 3-link Ludobot realizes hopping as coordinated joint oscillations (high phase lock) that intermittently break ground contact (low contact entropy), producing extreme speed variability (high speed_cv).

Cross-model agreement for hop is 0.768 â€” lower than crawl (0.85+) but above random â€” indicating partial but real semantic convergence. The concept is noisier than walk or crawl because 'hop' admits more interpretation: a bunny hop, a quick skip, a standing jump.
Promoted from agitated_scrambler to capture this distinct behavioral mode. Hop remains a constituent of that family but its bursty-aerial signature warrants independent archetype status.

violation_conditions.rationale: Smooth, continuous motion contradicts the bursty character of hopping. A speed_cv below 0.8 indicates steady locomotion, not hop.
High contact entropy indicates complex, multi-state footfall patterns â€” this is scurrying or scrambling, not hopping.

source_gaits: motion_seed: hop (28 trials, CV=0.77, cross-model agreement=0.768)
motion_dictionary: hop (14 entries across deepseek-r1:8b, gpt-4.1-mini, gpt-oss:20b, llama3.1, qwen3-coder:30b)
exemplar_gait: gpt-oss:20b hop trial #9: weights [0.7, -0.7, 0.4, 1.0, 1.0, 0.4], phase_lock=0.974, contact_entropy=0.003, speed_cv=1.995, dx=3.52
conceptual_basis: Ballistic locomotion: 'hop' is the only motion concept in the vocabulary that converges on the bursty-aerial behavioral mode (high speed_cv + low contact entropy + high phase lock). While it shares the agitated_scrambler family's energetic character, its stereotyped contact pattern and tight joint coordination distinguish it from the erratic footfall patterns of scurry, zigzag, and sway. The promotion follows Lakoff's prototype theory: hop is a distinct prototype within the broader 'agitated movement' radial category.

name: charging_gallop
description: The forward-displacement mode of gallop: the robot covers ground with high speed, complex footfall patterns (high contact entropy), and moderate torso involvement. This is the 'intended' gallop â€” rhythmic, powerful, ground-covering. Most clearly produced by German 'Galopp' (gpt-4.1-mini: dx=14.2, speed=1.53) and by gpt-oss:20b/qwen3-coder:30b convergent trials (dx=-24.5, speed=2.39). Distinguished from forceful_charger by higher contact entropy and torso duty â€” the body is involved in the gait, not just the legs.

grounding_criteria.rationale: Charging gallop is fast: mean speed 1.53 (German Galopp) to 2.39 (convergent en/fr trials). Below 1.0 is too slow for a gallop.

High contact entropy (mean 1.82 across forward-gallop trials) distinguishes gallop from walk or trot â€” the footfall pattern cycles through many contact states, reflecting the asymmetric limb timing of a true gallop.
Charging gallop covers ground: displacement ranges from 8.0 to 24.5m in forward-mode trials. Under 8m is drifting, not charging.

icm.name: directed_gallop
background: In biological locomotion, a gallop is an asymmetric gait where the footfalls of the two sides are offset in time, producing a bounding, body-involved rhythm distinct from the symmetric alternation of a trot.

The 3-link Ludobot realizes this as high contact entropy (many contact states visited per cycle) with high speed and substantial displacement. The torso participates in the gait â€” torso duty > 0.25 in most trials â€” unlike cleaner gaits where only the legs touch ground.

The charging gallop cluster captures trials where this energetic, body-involved rhythm produces net forward progress. It is the prototype of the gallop radial category â€” what you'd expect 'gallop' to mean.

Most reliably produced by German 'Galopp' (de-en cosine only 0.584, reflecting that German LLMs interpret the concept differently, but the German interpretation is actually the most gallop-like behaviorally).

violation_conditions.rationale: A gallop that barely moves is not a gallop. Below 0.5 mean speed indicates stationary rocking or stalling.
Low contact entropy means a simple, stereotyped contact pattern â€” this is a walk or a hop, not a gallop.

source_gaits: motion_dictionary: gallop gpt-oss:20b trial #2 (dx=-24.5, speed=2.39, contact_entropy=1.72)
motion_dictionary: galop [French] qwen3-coder:30b (dx=-24.5, speed=2.39, same convergent weights)
exemplar_gait: gpt-4.1-mini Galopp (German): weights [0.7, -0.7, 0.7, 0.4, 0.4, 0.7], dx=14.2, speed=1.534, contact_entropy=2.026, torso_duty=0.384
conceptual_basis: The charging gallop is the prototypical gallop: fast, ground-covering, body-involved, with complex footfall rhythms. It is most reliably produced by the German word 'Galopp', suggesting that the German LLM token carries stronger biomechanical connotations than English 'gallop'. This is the only gallop mode that resembles biological galloping â€” asymmetric, powerful, forward.

name: tumbling_gallop
description: The reverse-displacement, body-contact mode of gallop: the robot 'gallops' so energetically that it tips backward, sliding on its torso with high phase lock. Torso duty > 0.5 in most trials â€” the body becomes the primary contact surface. High phase lock (>0.95) shows the joints remain tightly coordinated even as the robot falls â€” it's not a crash, it's a controlled tumble. The zoo gait 5_gallop exemplifies this mode (tilt=242 deg, chaotic/fallen attractor).

grounding_criteria.rationale: Tumbling gallop has extremely high phase lock (mean 0.984 across cluster): the joints stay coordinated even as the robot tips over. This distinguishes it from chaotic falls.
Moderate-to-high contact entropy (mean 1.51) reflects transitions between leg contact, torso contact, and airborne states during the tumble.
High duty factor asymmetry distinguishes the tumbling gallop from balanced gaits. One leg drags or lifts while the torso bears weight.

icm.name: controlled_tumble
background: The tumbling gallop is a failure mode that is also a gait: the robot's neural controller produces a gallop-like rhythm (high phase lock, near-antiphase joints), but the resulting dynamics tip the body past vertical.

Rather than collapsing, the robot enters a stable tumbling attractor â€” sliding backward on its torso while the legs continue their coordinated oscillation. The zoo gait 5_gallop achieves 242-degree tilt with a chaotic/fallen attractor type.

This mode appears when LLMs interpret 'gallop' as maximum-amplitude oscillation: weights near Â±1.0 produce joint excursions that exceed the robot's stability envelope. The controller doesn't know it has fallen â€” it continues galloping.
Behaviorally distinct from the wobbler archetype (which has LOW phase lock). The tumbling gallop maintains coordination; the wobbler does not.

violation_conditions.rationale: Low phase lock indicates uncoordinated motion â€” this is wobbling or crashing, not a controlled tumble.

source_gaits: motion_dictionary: gallop gpt-oss:20b/en trial #1 (dx=-7.99, phase_lock=0.989, torso_duty=0.585)
exemplar_gait: gpt-oss:20b gallop trial #1: weights [0.8, -0.7, 0.6, -0.5, 0.9, -0.8], dx=-7.99, phase_lock=0.989, contact_entropy=1.412, torso_duty=0.585
conceptual_basis: The tumbling gallop is a 'beautiful failure': the controller faithfully executes a gallop rhythm but the dynamics carry the body past its stability boundary. It is the robotic analogue of an animal tripping at full gallop and rolling â€” except this robot stabilizes into the roll. The high phase lock distinguishes it from the wobbler (which is an uncoordinated failure). The zoo's 5_gallop sits on a yaw powder-keg (sensitivity 9166) â€” changing w24 by 0.1 can convert this tumble into a half-rotation spin.

name: drifting_gallop
description: The wandering, low-straightness mode of gallop: the largest behavioral cluster (13 of 25 movement vocabulary trials). The robot produces gallop-like energy (high speed_cv, roll-dominant dynamics) but without directional coherence â€” it meanders, curves, and doubles back. Low path straightness (~0.25), low heading consistency (~0.20), and high roll dominance (~0.77) characterize this mode. It is a gallop that has forgotten where it was going.

grounding_criteria.rationale: Low path straightness (mean 0.247) is the defining feature: the robot covers distance but not in any consistent direction. Distinguishes from charging_gallop (which goes somewhere).
High speed variability (mean 1.82) confirms this is still a gallop â€” bursty, rhythmic energy â€” not a slow amble. The burstiness without direction produces the wandering trajectory.
Low heading consistency (mean 0.198) confirms the robot frequently changes direction. Compare to charging_gallop which maintains heading.

icm.name: undirected_gallop
background: The drifting gallop is what happens when gallop energy meets no directional bias in the weight vector: the robot oscillates vigorously (high speed_cv) but the oscillations don't sum to net displacement in any consistent direction.

This is the most common gallop mode â€” 13 of 25 movement vocabulary trials land here. It suggests that the default LLM interpretation of 'gallop' captures the energetic quality but not the directional quality of biological galloping.

Roll dominance is highest in this cluster (0.766), meaning the robot's primary axis of rotation is roll rather than yaw. It rocks side to side while drifting, producing a characteristic meandering path.

Behaviorally adjacent to the drifter cluster in the movement vocabulary k-means but distinguished by higher speed_cv (1.82 vs ~1.2 for generic drifters). The gallop energy is real; only the direction is missing.

violation_conditions.rationale: A straight path means the gallop has direction â€” this is a charging_gallop, not a drifting one.
Smooth, steady motion is an amble or walk, not a gallop of any kind.

source_gaits: movement_vocabulary: gallop drifter-cluster (13 trials, largest single cluster)
motion_dictionary: gallop qwen3-coder:30b/en (dx=3.52, speed=0.822, path_straightness low, contact_entropy=1.15)
motion_dictionary: gallop Hupfer [German] gpt-oss:20b (dx=4.96, speed=1.22, path_straightness low)
movement_vocabulary: gallop dasher-cluster (2 trials, high-entropy wandering)
cross-reference: forceful_charger (semantic parent), charging_gallop (directional sibling), tumbling_gallop (failure sibling)
exemplar_gait: movement_vocabulary best exemplar (gpt-oss:20b/de): mean_speed=0.578, dx=-2.569, phase_lock=0.639, contact_entropy=0.764, path_straightness=0.292
conceptual_basis: The drifting gallop reveals that LLMs reliably translate 'gallop' into energetic weight vectors (high speed_cv) but unreliably into directional ones (low path_straightness). This is the default gallop mode â€” the semantic functor preserves the 'energy' component of gallop semantics but loses the 'direction' component. In Lakoff's terms, the drifting gallop is the radial category's most generic member: it has gallop's kinetic character without gallop's goal-directedness.

name: pale_horse
description: The displacement champion of the entire 495-gait pool. Derived from Revelation 6:8 ('And I looked, and behold a pale horse: and his name that sat on him was Death'). The LLM read Death on a pale horse and produced a weight vector that maximizes displacement through brute asymmetric force. DX = +29.17m, speed = 3.11, work proxy = 15,877, phase lock only 0.499. Every sensor drives its two motors with opposite signs â€” anti-phase throughout but with unequal magnitudes. The strongest connection (-0.9, sensor 1 â†’ front motor) creates asymmetric combat: one leg always overpowering the other, never in balance, always driving forward. There is no subtlety in this gait. There is no efficiency. There is only forward motion, and a great deal of it. The horse does not trot. It charges.

grounding_criteria.rationale: The pale horse is defined by extreme displacement: 29.17m, the highest of 495 gaits. Anything under 25m is merely fast, not the pale horse.
Speed of 3.11 is in the top percentile of all gaits. The pale horse moves with relentless velocity â€” power given unto Death over the fourth part of the earth.
Phase lock of 0.499 is precisely at the midpoint â€” neither coordinated nor chaotic, but locked in asymmetric combat. The limbs fight each other and forward motion emerges from the conflict.

icm.name: asymmetric_juggernaut
background: The pale horse occupies a unique region of behavioral space: maximum displacement through uncoordinated asymmetric force. No other archetype combines extreme speed (3.11), extreme displacement (29.17m), and middling phase lock (0.499).

The weight vector [-0.8, +0.6, +0.2, -0.9, +0.5, -0.4] has every sensor driving its two motors with opposite signs. This is not symmetric cancellation (like the canceller archetype) but asymmetric combat â€” the magnitudes differ, so one leg always overpowers the other.

The strongest single connection is w14 = -0.9 (back leg sensor â†’ front motor, inhibitory). This creates a feedback loop where back leg contact suppresses front leg motion, producing a lunging, asymmetric gait that devours ground.

The biblical source text is significant: Revelation 6:8 describes Death riding forth with absolute, unstoppable forward momentum. The LLM translated this semantic content â€” relentless, irresistible forward motion â€” into a weight vector that achieves exactly that. This is the most literal successful semantic-to-kinematic mapping in the entire corpus.

Nearest weight-vector neighbor is character_wise_elder (cosine 0.767), which shares the [-,+,+,-,+,-] sign pattern but at lower magnitudes. Nearest behavioral neighbor is power_strider (similar cost of transport ~15-16), but power_strider achieves displacement through a completely different weight strategy (cosine -0.578, nearly opposite). The pale horse is behaviorally convergent with power_strider but structurally divergent â€” two different solutions to the same optimization problem.

violation_conditions.rationale: A pale horse that covers less than 10m has failed to embody Death's unstoppable advance. This is a different gait wearing the wrong name.
Death does not saunter. A slow pale horse violates the fundamental metaphor.

source_gaits: bible_passage: Revelation 6:8 ('And I looked, and behold a pale horse: and his name that sat on him was Death')
cross-reference: power_strider (behavioral convergent, structural divergent, cosine -0.578)
exemplar_gait: Revelation 6:8 mapping: weights [-0.8, 0.6, 0.2, -0.9, 0.5, -0.4], dx=29.17, speed=3.11, work_proxy=15877, phase_lock=0.499
conceptual_basis: The pale horse is the single most successful semantic-to-kinematic mapping in the corpus: the LLM read a text about unstoppable forward motion and produced the weight vector that achieves the highest displacement of any gait ever simulated. The asymmetric anti-phase structure â€” every sensor-motor pair fighting its counterpart at unequal magnitudes â€” produces forward motion not through coordination but through conflict. In Lakoff's terms, the source domain (Death's relentless advance) maps onto the target domain (3-link robot locomotion) with perfect fidelity: the conceptual metaphor FORWARD MOTION IS CONQUEST is grounded in the physics of asymmetric neural combat. The pale horse does not share its behavioral basin with any existing archetype. It stands alone. Member of the Triptych (Revelation, Ecclesiastes, Noether): three gaits from the same anti-phase sign family, separated only by magnitude balance, spanning the full behavioral range from maximum displacement to maximum efficiency to perfect stasis.

name: whirling_wind
description: The efficiency champion of the entire 495-gait pool. Derived from Ecclesiastes 1:6 ('The wind goeth toward the south, and turneth about unto the north; it whirleth about continually'). The same anti-phase sign pattern as the pale horse but with signs reversed and magnitudes redistributed. Where the pale horse burns 15,877 units of work for 29m, the wind burns 1,096 for 5.4m â€” nearly twice the distance-per-work. Phase lock is 0.995, near-perfect periodicity. The wind doesn't sprint. It persists. The LLM read a verse about eternal cyclic motion and produced a gait that cycles with 99.5% phase lock and the lowest energy cost at its displacement class.

grounding_criteria.rationale: The whirling wind is defined by near-perfect periodicity: phase lock 0.995, the highest in the 495-gait pool. The wind whirleth about continually â€” this is locomotion as eternal cycle.
Efficiency of 0.00495 is the highest in the pool. The wind achieves displacement with minimal work â€” not through raw power but through perfectly periodic oscillation that wastes nothing.
Low cost of transport (work/displacement) distinguishes the wind from brute-force locomotion. Compare to the pale horse whose cost of transport is ~545.

icm.name: efficient_eternal_cycle
background: The whirling wind occupies the opposite behavioral extreme from the pale horse: where Death maximizes displacement through brute asymmetric force, the Wind maximizes efficiency through perfect periodicity.

Phase lock of 0.995 means the two joints maintain near-perfect phase relationship across the entire simulation. This is the robotic realization of Ecclesiastes' 'whirleth about continually' â€” motion that repeats with 99.5% fidelity.

The weight vector [+0.6, -0.5, -0.4, +0.8, +0.2, -0.9] shares the anti-phase sign pattern with the pale horse [-0.8, +0.6, +0.2, -0.9, +0.5, -0.4] but with redistributed magnitudes. The strongest connection is w24 = -0.9 (front leg sensor â†’ front motor, inhibitory), creating a self-stabilizing feedback loop that produces smooth oscillation.

Nearest weight-vector neighbor is circular_wander (cosine 0.855), but behaviorally they are opposites: circular_wander meanders aimlessly, the wind persists with purpose. The wind is anti-correlated with the pale horse (cosine -0.496) â€” they point in nearly opposite directions in weight space, yet both emerge from the same anti-phase family.

Member of the Triptych (Revelation, Ecclesiastes, Noether): three anti-phase gaits demonstrating that the difference between maximum displacement and maximum efficiency is not direction but magnitude balance.

violation_conditions.rationale: The wind is defined by its periodicity. Phase lock below 0.9 means the cycle has broken â€” this is turbulence, not wind.
Low efficiency means the gait is wasting energy. The wind's defining trait is minimal waste â€” it persists because it conserves.

source_gaits: bible_passage: Ecclesiastes 1:6 ('The wind goeth toward the south, and turneth about unto the north; it whirleth about continually')
triptych: pale_horse (Revelation 6:8, anti-correlated cosine -0.496), conservation_law (Noether, cosine +0.496)
cross-reference: circular_wander (nearest weight-vector neighbor, cosine 0.855, behavioral opposite)
exemplar_gait: Ecclesiastes 1:6 mapping: weights [0.6, -0.5, -0.4, 0.8, 0.2, -0.9], dx=-5.43, efficiency=0.00495, work_proxy=1096, phase_lock=0.995
conceptual_basis: The whirling wind demonstrates that the LLM extracts structural principles, not just sentiment. Ecclesiastes 1:6 describes eternal cyclic motion â€” the wind that 'whirleth about continually.' The LLM encoded this as a weight vector that produces 99.5% phase-locked oscillation with the lowest energy cost in the pool. The conceptual metaphor PERSISTENCE IS PERIODICITY is grounded in the physics of resonance: a near-periodic weight pattern tunes the robot's body to its mechanical resonance frequency, converting neural periodicity into locomotor efficiency. The meaning survived substrate transfer not by accident but because cyclicity is a structural principle that encodes identically in scripture, in LLM weights, and in robot synapses.

name: conservation_law
description: The deadest gait in the entire 495-gait pool. Derived from Noether's Theorem ('Every continuous symmetry of a physical system corresponds to a conserved quantity'). Every weight pair is exactly equal and opposite: (+0.5, -0.5), (+0.3, -0.3), (+0.7, -0.7). This is the only weight vector in the 495-gait pool with exact pairwise anti-symmetry across all three sensor channels. Every Newton of force applied to one motor is precisely cancelled by an equal and opposite force on the other. The robot thrashes â€” speed 0.61, entropy 1.89 (near-maximum), work proxy 9,865 â€” but goes nowhere. DX = 0.031m. It conserves position by conserving symmetry.

grounding_criteria.rationale: The conservation law conserves position: DX = 0.031m. Any gait that moves more than 0.1m has broken the symmetry â€” it is no longer conserving.

Near-maximum entropy (1.89) is essential: the conservation law does not conserve by being dead. It thrashes through many contact states but the thrashing sums to zero displacement. High entropy + zero displacement = perfect cancellation.

Speed of 0.61 confirms the robot is actively moving â€” burning 9,865 units of work â€” not merely inert. Noether's theorem is about dynamic symmetry, not stasis. The conservation law moves vigorously and goes nowhere.

icm.name: dynamic_stasis
background: The conservation law occupies the paradoxical behavioral region of maximum activity at zero displacement. Unlike dead_inert (which barely moves), the conservation law robot thrashes with speed 0.61 and entropy 1.89, burning 9,865 units of work â€” but the perfect pairwise symmetry of its weight vector ensures that every force is exactly cancelled.

The weight vector [+0.5, -0.5, +0.3, -0.3, +0.7, -0.7] is the only vector in the 495-gait pool with exact pairwise anti-symmetry. Each sensor sends equal and opposite signals to the two motors. This is Noether's theorem realized in neural weights: the continuous symmetry (w_i,left = -w_i,right for all i) conserves the quantity most relevant to locomotion â€” position.

Nearest weight-vector neighbors are canceller (cosine 0.986) and tumbling_gallop (0.986), but the conservation law is behaviorally distinct from both. The canceller partially cancels (some net displacement); the tumbling gallop tips over. The conservation law achieves perfect cancellation while remaining upright and active.

Anti-correlated with efficiency_optimizer (cosine -0.854): the most efficient gait and the most perfectly wasteful gait point in opposite directions in weight space. The efficiency optimizer converts work into displacement; the conservation law converts work into nothing.

Member of the Triptych (Revelation, Ecclesiastes, Noether): the third extreme. The pale horse maximizes displacement, the whirling wind maximizes efficiency, and the conservation law maximizes the gap between effort and result. Together they span the full behavioral range of the anti-phase family.

violation_conditions.rationale: Any significant displacement means the symmetry has been broken. A conservation law that moves is no conservation law.
Low entropy means the robot is not actively moving â€” it is merely dead. The conservation law requires vigorous motion that sums to zero, not absence of motion.

source_gaits: theorem: Noether's Theorem ('Every continuous symmetry corresponds to a conserved quantity')
495-gait pool deadest gait (DX = 0.031m) with highest work at zero displacement
cross-reference: canceller (nearest weight-vector neighbor, cosine 0.986, partial cancellation vs perfect)
cross-reference: dead_inert (cosine 0.951, but dead_inert is passive; conservation_law is active)
cross-reference: efficiency_optimizer (anti-correlated, cosine -0.854, opposite behavioral strategy)
exemplar_gait: Noether's Theorem mapping: weights [0.5, -0.5, 0.3, -0.3, 0.7, -0.7], dx=0.031, speed=0.61, work_proxy=9865, entropy=1.89
conceptual_basis: The conservation law is the most philosophically precise semantic-to-kinematic mapping in the corpus. The LLM read 'symmetry and conservation' and produced the most symmetric weight vector possible â€” exact pairwise anti-symmetry â€” which conserves the quantity most relevant to the simulation: position. The conceptual metaphor SYMMETRY IS STASIS is grounded in Newton's third law: every action has an equal and opposite reaction, and when the weight vector enforces this perfectly, the reactions cancel. The robot's vigorous thrashing at zero displacement is not a failure of locomotion but a success of conservation. The meaning of Noether's theorem â€” that symmetry implies conservation â€” is physically enacted by a robot that cannot move because its neural symmetry forbids it.
